fact: Did you know? The Sun accounts for 99.86% of the mass in our solar system.
Did you know? Jupiter is so large that all other planets in the solar system could fit inside it.
Did you know? The Hubble Space Telescope has taken over 1.3 million observations since 1990.
Did you know? Black holes can warp space and time so much that light cannot escape them.
Did you know? Astronauts aboard the ISS experience 16 sunrises and sunsets every day.
Did you know? Saturn has the most spectacular rings, made mostly of ice and rock particles.
Did you know? Voyager 1, launched in 1977, is the farthest human-made object from Earth.
Did you know? Neutron stars are so dense that a sugar-cube-sized amount of material would weigh billions of tons on Earth.
Did you know? The first human in space was Yuri Gagarin in 1961.
Did you know? The Milky Way contains over 100 billion stars.
Did you know? Mars has the tallest volcano in the solar system, Olympus Mons, three times taller than Mount Everest.
Did you know? The James Webb Space Telescope observes infrared light to see distant galaxies.
Did you know? Dark matter makes up about 27% of the universe, but we cannot see it directly.
Did you know? Astronauts grow slightly taller in space due to the lack of gravity compressing their spine.
Did you know? Mercury is the fastest orbiting planet, completing a trip around the Sun in just 88 Earth days.
Did you know? The first human-made satellite, Sputnik 1, was launched in 1957 by the Soviet Union.
Did you know? The universe is about 13.8 billion years old.
Did you know? Venus has a surface temperature hot enough to melt lead, around 465°C (869°F).
Did you know? The first woman in space was Valentina Tereshkova in 1963.
Did you know? Pulsars are rotating neutron stars that emit beams of radiation like cosmic lighthouses.
Did you know? The Moon is moving away from Earth at a rate of about 3.8 cm per year.
Did you know? The Apollo 11 mission in 1969 was the first time humans landed on the Moon.
Did you know? A light-year is the distance light travels in one year, about 9.46 trillion kilometers.
Did you know? The International Space Station has been continuously occupied since 2000.
Did you know? Uranus rotates on its side, making its seasons extreme.
Did you know? The first spacecraft to leave the solar system was Voyager 1 in 2012.
Did you know? Galaxies can collide and merge, forming new galaxies over billions of years.
Did you know? Black holes can evaporate slowly over time via Hawking radiation.
Did you know? SpaceX’s Falcon 9 rocket is reusable, reducing the cost of access to space.
Did you know? Mars has two moons, Phobos and Deimos, which are thought to be captured asteroids.
Did you know? The Andromeda Galaxy is on a collision course with the Milky Way in about 4 billion years.
Did you know? The James Webb Space Telescope launched in 2021 to study the early universe.
Did you know? Mercury has almost no atmosphere, so temperatures swing drastically from day to night.
Did you know? Astronauts' hearts can shrink slightly after spending extended time in microgravity.
Did you know? The first probe to reach Pluto was NASA’s New Horizons in 2015.
Did you know? Saturn’s moon Titan has lakes of liquid methane and ethane.
Did you know? The universe is expanding, and distant galaxies are moving away from us.
Did you know? The Milky Way is part of a cluster of galaxies called the Local Group.
Did you know? The first rover on Mars was Sojourner, part of the Mars Pathfinder mission in 1997.
Did you know? Jupiter’s Great Red Spot is a giant storm larger than Earth and has lasted for centuries.
Did you know? Astronauts need to exercise in space to prevent muscle atrophy.
Did you know? The Moon has moonquakes caused by tidal forces from Earth.
Did you know? The universe may contain more than 2 trillion galaxies.
Did you know? The first artificial satellite to orbit Earth was Sputnik 1 in 1957.
Did you know? Venus rotates backward compared to most planets in the solar system.
Did you know? The International Space Station orbits Earth at about 28,000 km/h.
Did you know? Black holes are detected indirectly by observing their effects on nearby stars and gas.
Did you know? Neptune has supersonic winds reaching over 2,000 km/h.
Did you know? Astronauts’ bones lose density in microgravity if not exercised regularly.
Did you know? Space telescopes avoid atmospheric distortion, allowing them to capture clearer images than Earth-based telescopes.
Did you know? The largest volcano in the solar system, Olympus Mons, is on Mars and is about 22 km high.
Did you know? The first human to perform a spacewalk was Alexei Leonov in 1965.
Did you know? Neutron stars can spin up to 700 times per second, emitting powerful beams of radiation.
Did you know? Saturn is less dense than water; if there were a giant bathtub, it would float!
Did you know? The Parker Solar Probe, launched in 2018, travels closer to the Sun than any spacecraft before it.
Did you know? A light-minute is the distance light travels in one minute, about 18 million km.
Did you know? Astronauts’ taste buds can change in space, making food taste blander.
Did you know? The Sun’s core temperature reaches about 15 million °C.
Did you know? Mercury experiences extreme temperature changes: up to 430°C in the day and -180°C at night.
Did you know? The first reusable spacecraft was the Space Shuttle, which flew from 1981 to 2011.
Did you know? The Milky Way has a supermassive black hole at its center called Sagittarius A*.
Did you know? Mars has the largest canyon in the solar system, Valles Marineris, over 4,000 km long.
Did you know? The first woman to perform a spacewalk was Svetlana Savitskaya in 1984.
Did you know? Cosmic rays are high-energy particles from space that can penetrate Earth's atmosphere.

Did you know? The first orbital flight by humans was Vostok 1 with Yuri Gagarin in 1961.
Did you know? Pulsars emit radio waves at extremely regular intervals, which can be used as cosmic clocks.
Did you know? Jupiter has 95 known moons, including the largest, Ganymede, bigger than Mercury.

Did you know? Saturn has 82 confirmed moons, each with unique features.
Did you know? Astronauts often exercise two hours daily to counteract muscle and bone loss in microgravity.
Did you know? The Hubble Space Telescope helped determine the universe is expanding at an accelerating rate.
Did you know? Uranus has a ring system, but it is faint and difficult to see from Earth.
Did you know? The Voyager probes carry a golden record with sounds and images of Earth for potential extraterrestrial life.
Did you know? The universe may be infinite, with no boundary or edge.
Did you know? The Sun rotates faster at the equator than at its poles, a phenomenon called differential rotation.
Did you know? Mars has the largest dust storms in the solar system, sometimes covering the entire planet.
Did you know? The ISS has a cupola module, allowing astronauts a panoramic view of Earth and space.
Did you know? The Milky Way is estimated to have over 100 billion planets.
Did you know? The first reusable rocket to reach orbit was SpaceX Falcon 9 in 2015.
Did you know? Mercury has a magnetic field, though much weaker than Earth's.
Did you know? Astronauts can suffer from 'space fog,' a temporary cognitive slowdown in microgravity.
Did you know? The Crab Nebula is the remnant of a supernova that exploded in 1054 AD.
Did you know? Neptune has 14 known moons, with Triton being the largest.
Did you know? The first private spacecraft to reach orbit was SpaceShipOne in 2004.
Did you know? Quasars are extremely bright and distant active galactic nuclei powered by supermassive black holes.

Did you know? The Sun’s corona is hotter than its surface, reaching millions of degrees Celsius.
Did you know? Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet in 2006.

Did you know? The fastest spinning planet is Jupiter, rotating once every 10 hours.

Did you know? The Andromeda Galaxy contains about one trillion stars.
Did you know? The Moon is the only celestial body humans have visited besides Earth.
Did you know? Voyager 2 is the only spacecraft to have visited Uranus and Neptune up close.
Did you know? Black holes are invisible, but their presence is inferred by the gravitational effects on nearby matter.
Did you know? Space telescopes like Chandra detect X-rays that are blocked by Earth's atmosphere.
Did you know? Mercury’s day is longer than its year, taking 59 Earth days to rotate once and 88 days to orbit the Sun.
Did you know? The first woman in space was Valentina Tereshkova aboard Vostok 6 in 1963.
Did you know? The Crab Pulsar spins around 30 times per second.
Did you know? Mars has polar ice caps made of water and carbon dioxide ice.
Did you know? Sputnik 1, launched in 1957, was the first artificial satellite to orbit Earth.
Did you know? Dark matter makes up about 27% of the universe, but we cannot see it directly.
Did you know? Astronauts’ bones lose about 1% mass per month in microgravity.
Did you know? Betelgeuse is a red supergiant star in Orion that could go supernova anytime in the next 100,000 years.
Did you know? Neptune’s atmosphere contains supersonic winds reaching up to 2,100 km/h.
Did you know? The Hubble Deep Field images show galaxies billions of light-years away, revealing the early universe.
Did you know? The first American in space was Alan Shepard in 1961 aboard Freedom 7.
Did you know? Black holes can grow by merging with other black holes or absorbing nearby matter.
Did you know? Venus rotates in the opposite direction to most planets, a retrograde rotation.
Did you know? The James Webb Space Telescope observes the universe in infrared light, allowing us to see early galaxies.
Did you know? The Sun’s core fuses about 600 million tons of hydrogen into helium every second.
Did you know? Earth’s magnetic field is generated by the motion of molten iron in its outer core.
Did you know? The International Space Station orbits Earth at about 28,000 km/h, completing 16 orbits per day.
Did you know? Galaxy collisions are common in the universe; our Milky Way will collide with Andromeda in 4 billion years.
Did you know? Titan, Saturn’s largest moon, has lakes of liquid methane and ethane.
Did you know? The first rover on the Moon was the Soviet Lunokhod 1 in 1970.
Did you know? Dark energy makes up about 68% of the universe and is driving its accelerating expansion.
Did you know? Astronauts on long missions often experience vision changes due to fluid shifts in microgravity.

Did you know? Mars has seasons similar to Earth because of its axial tilt of 25 degrees.

Did you know? Jupiter’s Great Red Spot is a storm larger than Earth that has lasted for centuries.

Did you know? Pulsars are neutron stars that emit radiation in pulses, like a cosmic lighthouse.
